dek: What our bodies do for work

stand_sit.text: Tell me a bit about your job.

body.text: For my job, I am required to…

environment.text: What are you exposed to at work?

salary.text: What is your salary range? (We won’t store your information.)

story.text: This circle represents a job that has similar physical requirements to yours. Each inside dot represents about 50,000 Americans who do that job.
Here are some other similar jobs. ← Some pay less and some pay more →
We’ll put you up here somewhere.
↓ These jobs on the bottom have very different physical demands from your job ↑
In the middle is every other job in America. Zoom and pan to explore the chart.
This story is about two kinds of workers in America: Sitters—people who sit for living—and Standers—those who stand, crouch, crawl, and lift.
We know the physical requirements of jobs from the Occupational Requirements Survey, a federal program to survey workers at more than 55,000 workplaces.

story.hl: Percent of day where sitting is required, mean
story.text: Let’s first look at ↑ Sitters. If you visited them at work at any given time, this is who would be sitting.

story.hl: Percent of workers, choice of sitting or standing is allowed
story.text: Some workers have the choice to sit or stand. This includes most high-paying jobs.

story.hl: Percent of workers, problem solving is required not every day, but at least once per week
story.text: These jobs are more likely to be about mental tasks. For example, these workers say they solve problems at least once a week.

story.hl: Percent of workers, with the ability to pause work
story.text: These jobs also tend to offer more autonomy. These are workers who say they can pause work when they need to.

story.hl: Percent of workers, with telework available
story.text: In addition, Sitters are more likely to say they can work remotely. Only a tiny portion of Americans have this option.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.text: Now let’s focus on ↑ Standers. If you visited them at work, this is who would be standing at any given time.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.text: As you can tell, these jobs tend to ←pay less.

story.hl: Percent of workers, problem solving is required less often than monthly, including never
story.text: These workers are more likely to say they are never or rarely have to problem-solve for their job.

story.hl: Percent of workers, crouching is required
story.text: These workers are required to crouch – everyone from nurses to electricians.

story.hl: Percent of workers, climbing ladders, ropes, or scaffolds is required
story.text: These workers have to climb ladders, ropes, or scaffolds. This includes firefighters and janitors.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to wetness
story.text: This is who is exposed to wetness, like water, sewage, or bodily fluids.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to extreme heat
story.text: This is who is exposed to extreme heat from things like stoves and fires.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to outdoors
story.text: These are workers who are exposed to the outdoors—something that will become more and more dangerous as our planet warms.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to hazardous contaminants
story.text: And this is who is exposed to hazardous contaminants. This group includes mechanics and construction workers.

story.hl: Percent of workers, without the ability to pause work
story.text: Notably, many of these jobs lack autonomy. These workers say they lack control over when they can take a break.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.text: When I was a kid in the 1980s, I thought all jobs required standing most of the day. In fact, I thought work was synonymous with back-breaking labor.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.text: That’s because, shortly after I was born, my dad left engineering school to go into business.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.text: And my parents bought a dry-cleaning business.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.text: My first memories are in the back of my parent’s dry cleaning store, playing inside hanger boxes.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.text: I played with my imaginary friend. He was a lawyer, because we had once gone to a lawyer’s office and I was enamored that he sat for a living.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.job: Laborers and freight, stock, and material movers, hand
story.text: My parents sold the dry cleaning business, and then tried running a car stereo store and a vending machine business. Both were exhausting.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.job: Laborers and freight, stock, and material movers, hand
story.text: One day, I remember my dad was late coming home from work. I was worried sick.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.job: Laborers and freight, stock, and material movers, hand
story.text: Finally, he called to check in: His hand got stuck in a vending machine gear. He had to call the fire department to get it unstuck.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.text: A year later, my dad chose to go back to school to be an engineer. He’s loved it ever since.
